s0001.chinese: 高祖，沛豐邑中陽里人也，姓劉氏。
s0001.literal: Gaozu was a person from Zhongyang Village, Fengyi Township, Pei County, and his surname was Liu.
s0001.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu hailed from Zhongyang Village in Fengyi Township, Pei County, and bore the surname Liu.

s0002.chinese: 母媼嘗息大澤之陂，夢與神遇。
s0002.literal: His mother once rested by the bank of Daze Marsh, and dreamed that she encountered a god.
s0002.idiomatic: His mother once rested by the shore of Daze Marsh and dreamt of meeting a divine being.

s0003.chinese: 是時雷電晦冥，父太公往視，則見交龍於上。
s0003.literal: At that time there was thunder and lightning, darkness and obscurity; his father Taigong went to look, and then saw two dragons mating above.
s0003.idiomatic: Thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkened heavens; his father Taigong went to investigate and witnessed two dragons entwined above.

s0004.literal: Soon after she became pregnant, and then gave birth to Gaozu.
s0004.idiomatic: Soon after, she conceived and gave birth to Emperor Gaozu.

s0005.chinese: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。
s0005.literal: Gaozu as a person had a high nose and dragon-like face, beautiful beard and whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.
s0005.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu had a prominent nose, a dragon-like countenance, magnificent beard and whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.

s0006.literal: He was benevolent and loved people, had an open-hearted disposition.
s0006.idiomatic: He was benevolent and loved people, enjoying giving charity, and had an open-hearted disposition.

s0007.chinese: 常有大度，不事家人生產作 業。
s0007.literal: He constantly had great magnanimity, did not engage in household production and work.
s0007.idiomatic: He always showed great magnanimity and never concerned himself with household chores or farm work.

s0008.chinese: 及壯，試吏，為泗上亭長，廷中吏無所不狎侮。
s0008.literal: When he grew up, he tested for office, became the pavilion chief of Sishang, and in the court among the officials there was none he did not treat with familiarity and mockery.
s0008.idiomatic: When he came of age, he took the civil service examination and became the pavilion chief of Sishang. Among the officials in the county court, there was not one he did not treat with casual familiarity or mock.

s0009.literal: He was fond of wine and sex.

s0010.chinese: 常從王媼、武負貰酒，時飲醉臥，武負、王媼見其上常有怪。
s0010.literal: He constantly borrowed wine from Wang Po and Wu Fu, at times drank until drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Wang Po saw that above him there was constantly something strange.
s0010.idiomatic: He was always borrowing wine from Granny Wang and Old Wu. Sometimes he drank himself into a stupor and collapsed. Granny Wang and Old Wu noticed that strange apparitions often hovered above him.

s0011.chinese: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。
s0011.literal: Gaozu each time bought wine and stayed to drink, the wine bill was several times over.
s0011.idiomatic: Whenever Gaozu bought wine, he would stay and drink, running up bills several times the amount.

s0012.chinese: 及見怪，歲 竟，此兩家常折券棄責。
s0012.literal: When they saw the strange apparitions, at year's end, these two families constantly tore up the debt contracts and abandoned the debts.
s0012.idiomatic: Whenever they saw these strange apparitions, at year's end these two families would tear up their IOUs and forgive his debts.

s0013.chinese: 高祖常繇咸陽，縱觀秦皇帝，喟然大息，曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此矣！」
s0013.literal: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang, gazed freely at the Qin emperor, sighed deeply, said: 'Alas, a great man should be like this!'
s0013.idiomatic: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang and gazed upon the Qin emperor. He sighed deeply and said, 'Alas, this is how a true hero should live!'

s0014.chinese: 單父人呂公善沛令，辟仇，從之客，因家焉。
s0014.literal: Lu Gong from Shanfu was friendly with the Pei magistrate, avoided enemies, became his guest, and thus settled his family there.
s0014.idiomatic: Lu Gong from Shanfu was on good terms with the magistrate of Pei. To avoid his enemies, he became the magistrate's guest and settled his family in Pei.

s0015.chinese: 沛中豪傑吏聞令有重客，皆往賀。
s0015.literal: The heroic officials and clerks in Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest, all went to congratulate him.
s0015.idiomatic: When the local notables and officials in Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest, they all came to offer congratulations.

s0016.chinese: 蕭何為主吏，主進，令諸 大夫曰：「進不滿千錢，坐之堂下。」
s0016.literal: Xiao He was the chief clerk, in charge of receiving guests, ordered the various gentlemen saying: 'Those who present less than a thousand cash, seat them below the hall.'
s0016.idiomatic: Xiao He, the chief clerk overseeing the reception, instructed the guests: 'Anyone who brings less than a thousand cash in congratulations should be seated below in the courtyard.'

s0017.chinese: 高祖為亭長，素易諸吏，乃紿為謁曰「賀錢萬」，實不持一錢。
s0017.literal: Gaozu was a pavilion chief, usually treated the officials casually, then lied in his calling card saying 'congratulatory money ten thousand', actually did not bring a single cash.
s0017.idiomatic: Gaozu, being a mere pavilion chief, was accustomed to treating officials casually. He forged a calling card claiming 'ten thousand cash in congratulations,' but brought nothing at all.

s0018.chinese: 謁入，呂公大驚，起，迎之門。
s0018.literal: The calling card entered, Lu Gong greatly astonished, rose, welcomed him at the gate.
s0018.idiomatic: When the calling card was presented, Lu Gong was astonished. He rose and went out to welcome him at the gate.

s0019.chinese: 呂公者，好相人，見高祖狀 貌，因重敬之，引入坐上坐。
s0019.literal: Lu Gong was fond of physiognomy, saw Gaozu's appearance, thus greatly respected him, led him in and seated him in the seat of honor.
s0019.idiomatic: Lu Gong was an expert in reading faces. When he saw Gaozu's features, he was filled with respect and seated him in the place of honor.

s0020.chinese: 蕭何曰：「劉季固多大言，少成事。」
s0020.literal: Xiao He said: 'Liu Ji indeed makes many great boasts, accomplishes few things.'
s0020.idiomatic: Xiao He said, 'Liu Ji talks big but gets little done.'

s0021.chinese: 高祖因狎侮諸客，遂坐上坐，無所詘。
s0021.literal: Gaozu thus familiarly mocked the various guests, then sat in the seat of honor, without yielding.
s0021.idiomatic: Gaozu casually mocked the other guests and took the seat of honor without any deference.

s0022.chinese: 酒闌，呂公因目固留高祖。
s0022.literal: The wine feast ended, Lu Gong thus gave meaningful looks and firmly detained Gaozu.
s0022.idiomatic: As the banquet wound down, Lu Gong gave meaningful glances and insisted on keeping Gaozu behind.

s0024.chinese: 呂公曰：「臣少好 相人，相人多矣，無如季相，願季自愛。
s0024.literal: Lu Gong said: 'I from youth liked physiognomy, have read many people's faces, none like Ji's features, wish Ji to take care of himself.'
s0024.idiomatic: Lu Gong said, 'Since youth I've loved reading faces. I've seen many people, but none with features like yours, Liu Ji. I hope you'll take good care of yourself.'

s0025.literal: 'I have a young daughter, wish to be a broom and mat servant.'
s0025.idiomatic: 'I have a daughter of marriageable age whom I would like to offer as your wife.'

s0026.chinese: 酒罷，呂媼怒呂公曰：「公始常欲奇此女，與貴人。
s0026.literal: The wine feast ended, Lady Lu angrily said to Lu Gong: 'You originally constantly wished to make this daughter extraordinary, give to a noble person.'
s0026.idiomatic: After the banquet, Lady Lu angrily confronted her husband: 'You always said this daughter was special and deserved to marry someone noble.'

s0027.chinese: 沛令善公，求之不與，何自妄許與劉季？」
s0027.literal: 'The Pei magistrate is friendly with you, sought her and you did not give, why arbitrarily promise to Liu Ji?'
s0027.idiomatic: 'The magistrate of Pei is your good friend. He asked for her hand and you refused. Why arbitrarily promise her to Liu Ji?'

s0028.chinese: 呂公曰：「此非兒女子所知。」
s0028.literal: Lu Gong said: 'This is not something women and children understand.'
s0028.idiomatic: Lu Gong replied, 'This is beyond the understanding of women and children.'

s0029.literal: In the end gave to Gaozu.
s0029.idiomatic: In the end, she was married to Emperor Gaozu.

s0030.chinese: 呂公女即呂后也，生孝惠帝、魯元公主。
s0030.literal: Lu Gong's daughter was Empress Lu, gave birth to Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan of Lu.
s0030.idiomatic: Lu Gong's daughter became Empress Lü, bearing Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan.

s0031.literal: Gaozu once took leave and returned to the fields.
s0031.idiomatic: Once Gaozu took leave to return to his farm.

s0032.chinese: 呂后與兩子居田中，有一老父過請飲，呂后因餔之。
s0032.literal: Empress Lu and her two children lived in the countryside, there was an old father who passed by requesting drink, Empress Lu thus fed him.
s0032.idiomatic: Empress Lü and her two children were living in the countryside when an old man passed by asking for something to drink. Empress Lü fed him.

s0033.chinese: 老父相后曰：「夫人天下貴人 也。」
s0033.literal: The old father read Empress Lu's face saying: 'Madam is a noble person of the world.'
s0033.idiomatic: The old man read her face and said, 'My lady, you are destined to be the most noble woman in the realm.'

s0034.chinese: 令相兩子，見孝惠帝，曰：「夫人所以貴者，乃此男也。」
s0034.literal: Ordered him to read the two children's faces, when he saw Emperor Hui, said: 'The reason madam is noble is this male child.'
s0034.idiomatic: He asked the old man to read the faces of her two children. When he saw Emperor Hui, he said, 'This boy is the source of your nobility, my lady.'

s0035.literal: Read Princess Lu Yuan's face, also all noble.
s0035.idiomatic: He read Princess Lu Yuan's face as well and declared that she too would be noble.

s0036.chinese: 老父已去，高祖適從旁舍來，呂后具言客有過，相我子母皆大貴。
s0036.literal: The old father had left, Gaozu happened to come from the neighboring house, Empress Lu completely told him the guest who passed by, read my children and mother all greatly noble.
s0036.idiomatic: After the old man left, Gaozu happened to arrive from the neighboring shed. Empress Lü told him everything about the visitor who had read their faces and predicted great nobility for her and her children.

s0037.idiomatic: Gaozu asked where he had gone. 'Not far,' she replied.

s0038.literal: Then pursued and caught up, questioned the old father.
s0038.idiomatic: Gaozu went after him and caught up, then questioned the old man.

s0039.chinese: 老父曰：「鄉者夫人兒子皆以君，君相貴不可言。」
s0039.literal: The old father said: 'Just now madam and children all take after you, your features noble beyond words.'
s0039.idiomatic: The old man said, 'Just now I read the faces of your wife and children. They all resemble you, and your features indicate nobility beyond description.'

s0040.chinese: 高祖乃謝曰：「誠如父言，不敢忘德。」
s0040.literal: Gaozu then thanked saying: 'Truly as father says, do not dare forget the kindness.'
s0040.idiomatic: Gaozu thanked him profusely: 'You speak truly, old sir. I will never forget your kindness.'

s0041.chinese: 及高祖貴，遂不知老父處。
s0041.literal: When Gaozu became noble, then did not know the old father's whereabouts.
s0041.idiomatic: When Gaozu rose to power, he could no longer find the old man.

s0042.chinese: 高祖為亭長，乃鲈竹皮為冠，令求盜之薛治，時時冠之，及貴常冠，所謂「劉氏冠」也。
s0042.literal: Gaozu as pavilion chief, then made a hat from sharkskin, ordered the thief-catcher from Xue to make it, wore it from time to time, and when noble constantly wore it, this is called 'Liu family hat'.
s0042.idiomatic: As pavilion chief, Gaozu had a hat made from sharkskin and ordered a blacksmith from Xue to craft it. He wore it occasionally then, and continued wearing it constantly after rising to power. This became known as the 'Liu family hat.'

s0043.chinese: 高祖以亭長為縣送徒驪山，徒多道亡。
s0043.literal: Gaozu as pavilion chief was ordered by the county to escort convicts to Mount Li, the convicts many fled on the road.
s0043.idiomatic: As pavilion chief, Gaozu was assigned by the county to escort convicts to Mount Li. Many of the convicts escaped along the way.

s0044.chinese: 自度比至皆亡之，到豐西澤中亭，止飲，夜皆解縱所送徒。
s0044.literal: He estimated that by the time he arrived all would have fled, arrived at the pavilion in the western marshes of Feng, stopped to drink, at night all released the convicts he was escorting.
s0044.idiomatic: He figured that by the time they reached Mount Li, all the convicts would have escaped. He stopped at a pavilion in Feng's western marshes for a drink, then released all the convicts under his charge that night.

s0046.chinese: 公等皆去，吾亦從此逝矣！」
s0046.literal: You gentlemen all go, I also from here depart!'
s0046.idiomatic: 'You may all go now. I too shall depart from here!'

s0047.chinese: 徒中壯士願從諸十餘人。
s0047.literal: Among the convicts the strong men who wished to follow were more than ten people.
s0047.idiomatic: Among the convicts, more than ten strong men chose to follow him.

s0048.chinese: 高祖被酒，夜徑澤中，令一人行前。
s0048.literal: Gaozu was drunk, at night went straight through the marshes, ordered one person to go ahead.
s0048.idiomatic: Gaozu, having drunk too much, traveled straight through the marshes at night and sent one man ahead to scout.

s0049.literal: The one who went ahead returned and reported saying: '

s0050.literal: Ahead there is a large snake blocking the path, wish to turn back.'
s0050.idiomatic: 'There's a huge snake blocking the path ahead. We should turn back.'
